page.lettertext:
fol.337r
Belgia 1592 October 10
May it please yo
r
good L. I was lately req
e
sted,
to come to
e assemblie of
e
General states
, where
one of them declared, in
e name of
e rest, That
they had given
M
r
Caron
his dispatche unto her
Ma
tie
and had proposed by their letters two special pointes
to be considered. One concerned
e w
t
drawing of
the companies from hens:
at
e Contract thereby was
apparantly infringed: because they have not
at
assistance,
at was promised unto them. They re-
quested in
e other,
at some order might be taken,
whereby their trafficke might be freed from the
Englishe adventurers, by whome
e marchants of
these contreis were notoriously wronged: and
at restitution might be made of all
e gooddes
at
Spoiles of the
Zelanders by
Englishmen
they detened: namely belonging to
e shippe of
Ter vere, and to two other shippes,
at have bin taken
very lately: of w
ch
one is of
Middelbourgh,
and
e
other of
Amsterdam.
In w
ch
three, as they say,
they have lost above
e valewe of
threescore thou
sand poundes sterlng:
e parties being in
En-
gland
by whome they have bin spoiled: char-
ging those shippes, w
ch
were at
e taking of
e
late Indian price: whome they accuse in like
meaner of unmercifull
tormenting and killing
of their mariners: concluding in
e end, and
protesting
e same very solemnly unto me, that
unles some order might be taken, and
at very spe-
dily, for redresse of those enormities, they were
sure it would occasion some great inconvenience.
fol.337v
For all their marchants in a maner, not onely in
the townes
at I mentioned before, but in sundrie
other places, did exclame very bitterly, and signifie
plainely to them,
at their abilitie would not suffer,
nor they could not have
e patience, to endure those in-
juries any longer. Wherupon they thought it re-
quisit, not onely to acquaint me, w
t
e effect of their
letters, but to intreat me to testifie
e discontentm
t
of
e contrey, and to concurre in procuring some re-
medy for it. I promised in my answer,
both to signifie as muche, as they had required, and to
doe my best endevo
r
, to advance their desires. But
yet first for
e point of breaking
e Treaty, I desi-
red to understand, to what effect they would have
me to write unto her Ma
tie
. If it were to solicit
e stay of
e companies, it was to be supposed, that
they were ether gone already, or would be gone very
shortly: and in all probabilitie, before it could be pos
sible to heare out of England. If their purpose
were rather, to have some certaine time appointed,
for returne of
e companies, upon intelligence there,
I would second it as muche, as they could looke f[or]
at my handes. But if they had no other mea[ning]
but to have me signifie in general,
at they int[erpret]
this imploiment of
e companies in
France,
to [be a]
breache of
e Treaty, it had bin done very of[ten]
and it was
e argument of their answear of [the]
14 of Sep
t
w
ch
I had sent unto her Ma
tie
.
Moreover it would revive an ancient content[ion]
fol.338r
about
e keeping of
e Contract, that me thoug[ht]
they should desire, to have it put
in
oblivion. For
if it came in any question between her Hig
es
and
them, it would be many waies declared, and prov[ed]
effectually,
at they had swarved so directly from
the meaning of
e Treatie in a multitude of cause[s]
as it could not be answeared w
t
any colourable
reason. Astouching those abuses
at were
offered to their marchants, I lette them understand
that I had newly receaved a copie of
e Articles
w
ch
M
r
Caron their Agent had exhibited in England
and had bin lately apostilled by
e judge of the
Admiraltie, w
ch
having delivered to him in this pla[ce]
I did not doubt but by him were imparted unto
them. And for ought
at I could see, their mar-
chants might be satisfied, w
t
those courses of justice
at had bin used in their affaires. Nevertheles if
they desired some other forme of proceeding, in
e
hearing of their causes, then had bin practised hi-
therto, and was usual in England, upon know
ledge in particular, to what order of dealing they
would willingly be subject, I would not faile, as I
might to recommend it to her Ma
tie
.
Having made my answear in this sort, I might
easely perceave,
at they had stoode at a kinde of stay,
wherof I knewe not then
e cause. For they repli-
ed but briefly to me, That they had written to her
Ma
tie
and wold leave it so as they had written,
to her Ma
ties
consideration. I had con-
ference after w
t
M
r
Caron, to whome I signified
fol.338v
what I had saied in
at meeting of
e states, and
howe nakedly they spake to that w
ch
I demaunded:
that I knewe not what to thinke, of their humo
rs
in
e maters,
at were moved unto me. Wherto
he answeared againe, but under benedicite, That
in his speeches unto them, when they gave him his
dispatche, he did cast in a maner
e self same doutes,
and desired to be informed of their full resolution,
aswell for requiring
e companies againe, as for
some order of proceeding in
e affaires of
e mar-
chants. W
t
all he shewed them
e forme of a certaine
Commission, w
ch
was graunted by her Ma
tie
e 25
of her raigne, to certaine of my
LL.
of
e privy Coun-
cell together w
t
some others, to examine and deter-
mine all causes of
at q
a
litie,
at should touche any
subject of
e
King of Scotland
. And if they would
be contended to accept of
e like, he persuaded them
to thinke,
at it would not be denied. To this
they told him againe,
at first for
e mater of
e En-
glishe companies, he should be no meanes be instant,
to have them sent againe hither: but onely in gene
ral termes make remonstrance of their grief, in
at
e Treatie was neglected. And for
e causes of
e marchants, they did not seeme to dislike of t[hat]
proceeding by way of commission: but yet they
would not of themselves become suitors to have [it.]
Because they thought by
at meanes
ei might be [over]
muche bounde, and admitte an ill president, [in]
referring
e decision of their causes into Englan[d.]
fol.339r
Of this I thought very fitte to advertise yo
r
L. yet
because it will turne M
r
Caron to displeasure, if
the states should understand it, and he would not
greatly like
at I should write it to yo
r
L. I would
willingly commit it as a secret to yo
r
self. I
had very litle hope,
at
e states would have used
his service any longer. For it is not for love
at is
boaren unto him by
e principall heere, nor for
any good liking
at they have of his dealing: because
they judge him to be partiall, and too muche ad-
dicted to her Ma
ties
designes. But they can hardly
finde an other,
at is both sufficient for
e place,
and a man of
at cariage, as is meete for them
to send to negotiat w
t
her Ma
tie
. What in-
tention
ei may have, in forbidding him expressely
to make any suite unto her Ma
tie
to returne her
assistance, I can not yet conjecture. For the
people of this contrey are diversly affected. Some
would persuade to have her Ma
tie
moved, to assist
them for heereafter in some other kinde of sort: as
by an annual summe of mony: whereby their turn
might be served, if
e summe were competent, to bette[r]
purpose then before. Others doe desire
e conti-
nuance of
e succo
rs
, but yet because they doe see
e
F
r
Kinges
necessitie, w
ch
they knowe must be re-
lieved by her Ma
tie
or by them, they are not muche
unwilling to their imploiment in Brittaine: sup
posing
at her Ma
tie
being once embarked in
at
warre, will maintene it so roundly, as this con-
trey will be eased in their imprests to
e King.
fol.339v
Some others thinke
at
e contrey is so assured
in every Province, as there is no necesitie of
her Hig
es
support. And to
e end they might enjoye
their gouvernment alone, and be quite of
at auto-
ritie w
ch
is due unto her by
e Contract, they
would gladly be ridde of all
e Englishe nation.
Whether of these conceats is in
e Deputies heere of
e
General states, I can not say w
t
any certaintie.
But once I am assured,
at howsoever their estate,
and
e qualitie of their persons doth minister cause
to make men thinke,
at their dealinges are as plaine
and inwardly
e same, as they are caried in out-
ward shewe, yet to say as I finde by their daily
proceeding, they are many of them wilie, and voide
of sinceritie, ill affected in their hartes, and un-
thankfull towardes her Ma
tie
. And whether it
be not needefull in
at respect, and for their p
nt
doubtfull dealing,
at some extraordinarie care
should be taken of
e Cautionarie townes, I knowe
yo
r
L. will consider. So muche
e more, for
at
e contrey at this p
nt
is greatly disquieted, w
t
these tidinges of
e torture and slaughter of their
sea men, and continuance of their losses, w
ch
are
amplified alwaies by
e marchants report, an[d]
e people made beleve,
at ether in England they [can]
not be heard, or
at
ei can not have justice. [which]
I knowe doth proceede of very passion and mali[ce]
through
e losse of their gooddes, but yet undou[tedly]
heere it is both a common speeche, and a cons[tant]
persuasion, aswell of
e chiefe, as of
e vulga[r]
sort of people: that unles they may receave
fol.340r
some speedy satisfaction, it can not choose but en-
gender some dangerous disorder. and howe soone
it may be wrought, by
e meanes of badde instru-
ments, of w
ch
these contreis have enough, I neede not
signifie to yo
r
L. It is written
from
Brussels,
at
e
King of Spaine
doth determine,
to send thither his sonne, to
e end
e people of those
Provinces may publikly accept him as lawfull heir
unto his father, and take an othe of obedience.
They signifie w
t
all,
at there is a model sent thither
for enlarging
e palace: w
ch
is also begonne, and
in hand already. This is thought to be a pra-
ctise, not onely to contene his owne in devotion, but
by some offers to compasse
e disuniting of thes[e]
contreis. Where it hath bin heere con-
cluded,
at there army yet in field, should passe
e Rhine about Embricke, to stoppe
e pasage of
e
E nemie: it was presently after understoode,
at
600 horse of
e Enemies strength were over already
and
at
e
Duke
in like maner was gone from
e
spa: Wherupon
Count Maurice
w
t
his campe,
attendeth about Embricke, to see w
at
verdugo
wil[l]
further attempt, w
t
e remainder of his forces: who
we heare at this present, doth not sturre out of
Oldenzeel
in
e
Twente,
having lost in a mutini[e]
for want of pay, 7 enseignes of footemen, w
ch
are
wholy debanded, and 5 cornets of horse,
at are
passed
e Rhine. It is said thereupon
at Count
Maurice is gone to doe some exploit: but whether
it be to fight w
t
verdugo, while his souldiers do mutinie,
fol.340v
or to attempt somwhat els, it is not certified unto
us. But unles it be to surprise some palce of the
Enemie, or to doe some soddaine service by way of
incursion,
e yere is so muche spent, and heere
hath fallen so muche raine, for two monethes together,
that it is not possible for
e souldiers, to keepe
e
field any longer, in a contrey full of marishes.
And thus for this present I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Oc
t
10 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
